docs.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, a young woman named Frances Burge was found dead in Greenwich, Conn., hanging by a rope from the deck of a luxurious house. On one level, the death, ruled a suicide, was a personal tragedy, the sad end to a troubled life.

headline.main: Woman's Suicide a Bizarre Note in Fraud Inquiry

docs.abstract: Frances Burge was found dead two years ago, hanging by rope from deck of Martin R Frankel's luxurious Greenwich, Conn, house; her death, which was ruled suicide, and year leading up to it, provide unusual insight into life of Frankel, shadowy businessman sought by authorities in fraud case; Federal authorities say Frankel defrauded insurance companies in several states of hundreds of millions of dollars; Greenwich police say he attracted many women to his mansion; say Burge worked for him as gal Friday, hoping to fulfill her dreams of money and excitement; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Two years ago, a young woman named Frances Burge was found dead in Greenwich, Conn., hanging by a rope from the deck of a luxurious house.    On one level, the death, ruled a suicide, was a personal tragedy, the sad end to a troubled life.

docs.lead_paragraph: Before Serbia went to war with the West, Vesna Markovic wanted three children. Since the Kosovo conflict, she has often been sorry that she has one. To raise the money to provide her 8-year-old son with food, clothes and toys, Mrs. Markovic, 27, an economist who works at an electric utility in Belgrade, has become a smuggler of gasoline and disposable diapers.

headline.main: Stresses of Milosevic's Rule Blamed for Decline in Births

docs.abstract: Serbian women in unprecedented numbers are deciding not to have children, primiarly because of anxiety about the war in Kosovo, fear of civil war in Serbia and unwillingness to raise children in a nation whose standard of living has declined every year for the past decade; abortion rate appears to be rising sharply and increasing numbers of young women are telling doctors they do not want to give birth; photo; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: EVERY Tuesday and Thursday morning at 8, Dr. Domenica Vacca, an obstetrician-gynecologist who quit practicing medicine two years ago when her son was born, arrives for work at a white-shingled three-story building in rural Owings, Md. For the next eight hours, she sits in front of a computer terminal and holds private electronic conversations with people seeking her advice on everything from herpes to menopause. In her part-time job with Ask the Doc, a service offered free by AmericasDoctor.com, Dr. Vacca traverses delicate legal territory. A lengthy on-screen disclaimer informs her questioners that the company's Internet doctors -- it employs more than 100 -- ''will not engage in any conduct that involves the practice of medicine.'' They will not diagnose illness, prescribe medication, keep a medical record of the conversation or even reveal their identities. But they do provide something the callers' own doctors often can't give: peace of mind.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; From M.D. to I.P.O., Chasing Virtual Fortunes

docs.abstract: Comment on Internet medical sites, that are filling gap in time when managed care has put greater distance between doctors and patients; former Surgeon General C Everett Koop became 1999 Internet millionaire when his Web site, DrKoop.com, went public; Dr Daniel Carlin (WorldClinic) and Dr Tom Caffrey (Cyberdocs) discuss advice and 'virtual house calls'; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A United Nations conference reached agreement today on a plan to curb the world's population growth that includes recommendations that have drawn objections from several conservative Muslim and Roman Catholic countries. The 179 nations that met to assess progress toward goals set at the 1994 Cairo population conference adopted, by consensus, recommendations including unrestricted access to safe abortions in countries where it is legal, education in ''sexual and reproductive health issues'' at all school levels, and confidential contraceptive advice to ''sexually active adolescents.''

headline.main: Conference Adopts Plan On Limiting Population

docs.abstract: United Nations conference reaches agreement on plan to curb world's population growth; plan includes recommendations that have drawn objections from several conservative Muslim and Roman Catholic countries; recommendations include unrestricted access to safe abortions in countries where it is legal, and confidential contraceptive advice to 'sexually active adolescents'; new recommendations go far beyond those of plan set at 1994 Cairo population conference; Argentina, Nicaragua and Vatican file reservations (M)
